awd_titl_txt: K12 CS Pathways for Rural and Tribal Schools
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal will address the K12 Pathways strand and will develop sustainable computer science (CS) pathways in rural and tribal schools. The goal is to introduce CS to all students early in school and provide multiple opportunities to engage with CS during K12 and achieve identified learning outcomes, with emphasis on underrepresented groups.  Project team members have an existing research-practice partnership, specifically a networked improvement community, with the National Center for Computer Science Education as the hub and Fond du Lac Ojibwe School (FDLOS) and Hermantown Community Schools as network nodes.

Specifically, the researchers will engage in three distinct project activities to achieve the above goal.  These include: 1) Creating a computer science implementation plan for each district based on a scope and sequence for all K12 students, in alignment with Minnesota and CS Teachers Association student standards; 2) Designing sustainable CS professional development programs for rural and tribal schools, leveraging the involvement of tech integration specialists and administrators; and 3) Identifying needs of and supporting underrepresented students, in particular those in low socioeconomic status, special education, and Native American groups. Hence, the proposed work will explore school context, such as student cultural backgrounds, district size and available resources and their impact on students' CS learning. These are critical factors in the CSForAll discourse.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
Overall, each school made significant progress in establishing sustainable K-12 CS pathways for their students and staff. At the conclusion of the grant, each school has established a CS department or team that leads the school?s efforts and has the support of administration and teachers. They have also established routines for using the CSforALL SCRIPT rubrics to evaluate their progress and set goals on an annual basis. Details for each outcome are as follows:

  • Outcome1: Creating a computer science implementation plan for each district based on a scope and sequence for all K12 students, in alignment with Minnesota and CSTA student standards. 

    • Each school has a scope and sequence for CS learning for K-12 students

    • Each school has implemented an initial pathway for CS learning and has plans to review and refine that pathway over time

    • Each school has identified ways to sustain their CS programs, including staffing and funding

  • Outcome 2: Creating sustainable CS professional development programs for rural and tribal schools, leveraging the involvement of tech integration specialists and administrators. 

    • A majority of teachers at both schools have had at least 5 hours of CS professional development

    • Each school?s CS team is growing their skills and confidence in leading CS professional development specific to their context and teacher?s needs, whether that is identifying external opportunities and resources or leading the PD themselves

  • Outcome 3: Identifying needs of and supporting underrepresented students in computing, in particular low socioeconomic status (low-SES), special education, and American Indian students. 

    • Each school has a set of tools and resources they can draw upon to support students from each of the focal populations

    • CS teams in each school have had some experiences applying supports to these populations

 

This project also studied three research questions:

  • Research Question 1: What are the supports and barriers to implementing a K12 computer science pathway for all students in rural and tribal schools?

  • Research Question 2: How does the school context (district size, student cultural factors, staff profile, climate, resources, etc.) impact equity goals of broadening participation in computing, particularly for low-SES, special education, and American Indian students?

  • Research Question 3: What is the impact for rural and tribal schools of remote learning on computer science instruction and learning, in particular for low socioeconomic status (low-SES), special education, and American Indian students?

 

The supports for implementing a K12 CS pathway consisted of: 1) schools/districts developing clear vision statements about why CS learning is important for all students; 2) stable, encouraging, and collaborative administrative leadership; and 3) strong cohesive partnerships among project implementers.  Barriers included: 1) some turnover for project implementers early on in the project and 2) the COVID pandemic which slowed initial momentum for the project and led to remote learning for students.  For the tribal K12 school, elements of the school context (e.g., its commitment to providing the same learning experiences and resources for all students) aligned well with providing equitable CS learning opportunities for a student population that is majority American Indian, living in low-SES circumstances, and for many students who have special education designations.  In the rural school district, students who are American Indian, from low-SES families, or who have a special education designation are in the minority.  Highlighting the inequities in CS and learning why all students benefit from learning CS led to conversations about equity and action to broaden CS opportunities for all students.  Remote learning impacted staffing in both schools/districts in terms of turnover and changing work assignments.  Both schools/districts expanded their understanding of how their family and student communities lacked internet connectivity and the technological resources needed for remote learning.  They both worked quickly to distribute resources for remote learning but the tribal school noted that the pandemic disrupted their regular contact with some of their students.  Both schools/districts observed learning losses for students as well as setbacks in social and emotional learning.  As the pandemic continued, the challenges of moving back and forth between in-person teaching, hybrid models, and remote learning resulted in what staff at these schools referred to as ?COVID fatigue?.  When the pandemic began to subside and they returned to in-person learning, many of the project implementers felt that much of the forward progress in building the CS pathway with staff either stalled or was lost.  This did not prove to be the case long-term as the fourth and final year of the project saw meaningful progress in building awareness and support among teachers and staff and either expanding or creating new opportunities for all students to learn CS.

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2023
Modified by: Jennifer L Rosato

    Jennifer L Rosato
    Hermantown Professional Development, Spring 2023
  • Paul Schonfeld, District Support Coordinator, leads an activity at Fond du Lac Ojibwe School on algorithms for creating a peanut butter and jelly sandwich.
    Jennifer Rosato
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Jennifer L Rosato
    PB&J Algorithms Activity
  • Tour of Sugar Bush (iskigamizigan) at Fond du Lac Ojibwe School. Hermantown teachers learned from Fond du Lac Ojibwe School to start a Sugar Bush educational unit at Hermantown, incorporating data collection and CS learning combined with Ojibwe language and culture learning.
    Jennifer Rosato
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Jennifer L Rosato
    Sugar Bush Collaboration
  • 2023 Hawaii International Conference on Education panelists, presenting �Successes and Challenges in Developing K12 CS Pathways: Perspectives from a rural and a tribal school.� (L to R: Jodie Lockling, Dawn Liimatainen, Valerie Tanner, Brittany Heskin, Andy Olson, Mike Pothast)

por.por_txt_cntn:
Overall, each school made significant progress in establishing sustainable K-12 CS pathways for their students and staff. At the conclusion of the grant, each school has established a CS department or team that leads the school?s efforts and has the support of administration and teachers. They have also established routines for using the CSforALL SCRIPT rubrics to evaluate their progress and set goals on an annual basis. Details for each outcome are as follows:


Outcome1: Creating a computer science implementation plan for each district based on a scope and sequence for all K12 students, in alignment with Minnesota and CSTA student standards. 


Each school has a scope and sequence for CS learning for K-12 students


Each school has implemented an initial pathway for CS learning and has plans to review and refine that pathway over time


Each school has identified ways to sustain their CS programs, including staffing and funding




Outcome 2: Creating sustainable CS professional development programs for rural and tribal schools, leveraging the involvement of tech integration specialists and administrators. 


A majority of teachers at both schools have had at least 5 hours of CS professional development


Each school?s CS team is growing their skills and confidence in leading CS professional development specific to their context and teacher?s needs, whether that is identifying external opportunities and resources or leading the PD themselves




Outcome 3: Identifying needs of and supporting underrepresented students in computing, in particular low socioeconomic status (low-SES), special education, and American Indian students. 


Each school has a set of tools and resources they can draw upon to support students from each of the focal populations


CS teams in each school have had some experiences applying supports to these populations





 
This project also studied three research questions:


Research Question 1: What are the supports and barriers to implementing a K12 computer science pathway for all students in rural and tribal schools?


Research Question 2: How does the school context (district size, student cultural factors, staff profile, climate, resources, etc.) impact equity goals of broadening participation in computing, particularly for low-SES, special education, and American Indian students?


Research Question 3: What is the impact for rural and tribal schools of remote learning on computer science instruction and learning, in particular for low socioeconomic status (low-SES), special education, and American Indian students?



 
The supports for implementing a K12 CS pathway consisted of: 1) schools/districts developing clear vision statements about why CS learning is important for all students; 2) stable, encouraging, and collaborative administrative leadership; and 3) strong cohesive partnerships among project implementers.  Barriers included: 1) some turnover for project implementers early on in the project and 2) the COVID pandemic which slowed initial momentum for the project and led to remote learning for students.  For the tribal K12 school, elements of the school context (e.g., its commitment to providing the same learning experiences and resources for all students) aligned well with providing equitable CS learning opportunities for a student population that is majority American Indian, living in low-SES circumstances, and for many students who have special education designations.  In the rural school district, students who are American Indian, from low-SES families, or who have a special education designation are in the minority.  Highlighting the inequities in CS and learning why all students benefit from learning CS led to conversations about equity and action to broaden CS opportunities for all students.  Remote learning impacted staffing in both schools/districts in terms of turnover and changing work assignments.  Both schools/districts expanded their understanding of how their family and student communities lacked internet connectivity and the technological resources needed for remote learning.  They both worked quickly to distribute resources for remote learning but the tribal school noted that the pandemic disrupted their regular contact with some of their students.  Both schools/districts observed learning losses for students as well as setbacks in social and emotional learning.  As the pandemic continued, the challenges of moving back and forth between in-person teaching, hybrid models, and remote learning resulted in what staff at these schools referred to as ?COVID fatigue?.  When the pandemic began to subside and they returned to in-person learning, many of the project implementers felt that much of the forward progress in building the CS pathway with staff either stalled or was lost.  This did not prove to be the case long-term as the fourth and final year of the project saw meaningful progress in building awareness and support among teachers and staff and either expanding or creating new opportunities for all students to learn CS.
